content.introduction: Every programmer's journey starts with a single line of code. In this lesson, you'll learn how to make Python talk using the print() function.

explanation.content: The print() function is Python's way of displaying text on the screen. Whatever you put inside the parentheses gets printed out.

annotations.text: print() displays whatever is inside the parentheses

explanation.content: Text in Python is called a "string." You can create strings using either single quotes ('hello') or double quotes ("hello") — both work exactly the same way.

print('Single quotes work!')
print("Double quotes work too!")

metadata.output:
Single quotes work!
Double quotes work too!

explanation.content: You can print multiple things by separating them with commas. Python will add spaces between them automatically.

print("My name is", "PyQuest")
print("I am", 1, "year old")

metadata.output:
My name is PyQuest
I am 1 year old

annotations.text: The text inside quotes is called a 'string'

commonMistakes: Forgetting the parentheses: print "hello" won't work in Python 3. Always use print("hello").
Mismatched quotes: print('hello") will cause an error. Make sure your opening and closing quotes match.
Missing quotes around text: print(hello) without quotes looks for a variable named 'hello' instead of printing the word.
content.realWorldUse: The print() function is used everywhere in programming — from debugging code to creating user interfaces in terminal applications. Every Python developer uses it daily.

hints: Look at the text between the quotation marks.
print() displays exactly what's inside the quotes.
exercises.explanation: The print() function outputs the string exactly as written between the quotes.

exercises.explanation: print() is the function that displays text output in Python.

hints: Look carefully at the quotation marks.
Every opening quote needs a matching closing quote.
exercises.explanation: The closing double quote was missing. Strings must have matching opening and closing quotes.

exercises.prompt: Write code that prints your name on one line and "is learning Python" on the next line.
exercises.starterCode:
# Print your name on the first line
# Print "is learning Python" on the second line
hints: You need two separate print() statements.
Each print() creates a new line automatically.
Your name can be anything — just put it in quotes!
exercises.explanation: Each print() statement outputs its text and automatically moves to a new line. Using two print() calls puts text on two separate lines.

exercises.prompt: Which of these is the correct way to print text in Python 3?
hints: The text needs to be inside quotes.
exercises.explanation: In Python 3, print() is a function that requires parentheses. The text must be wrapped in quotes (single or double).
